We were having a debate in my politics class around the suggestion that Australia should adopt a bill of rights, the main comparison was with America's Bill of Rights. 
 Unfortunately all the class could do was to speculate on the evidence provided through research, i would really love to hear first hand any opinions from those who live in a country with a functioning bill of rights; whats your opinion on it? is it a good thing or a bad thing? would it benefit Australia to adopt one?

 Unfortunately all the class could do was to speculate on the evidence provided through research, i would really love to hear first hand any opinions from those who live in a country with a functioning bill of rights; whats your opinion on it? is it a good thing or a bad thing? would it benefit Australia to adopt one?

 
 I absolutely support the concept and principles which our Bill of Rights represents. I would find it hard to believe that any citizen of any Country could read it and not want the personal protections it affords the average citizen. 
 
 I believe it has withstood the test of time and has protected the individual rights of countless Americans from Government abuse and tyranny. 
 
 Bill of Rights

I have to say there are quiet a few of ammendments in your Bill of Rights that i would love to see here, freedom of opinion resonates quiet loudly! we cant say anything here without threats of defamation suits running rife.
 
 With regards to the increase in power of the judiciary, what do you guys think about Canada's "notwithstanding clause"?

I think a downside of a bill of rights is that it does not allow for incrementalism. It creates two adversarial sides and drives the law to one end or the other. The obvious example is abortion, which is by law an absolute right in the US, even though 40%+ of the population consider it to be murder, because the nature of the bill of rights concludes that life must begin at either birth or conception. In Britain, the law on abortion is far more complex, and still theoretically requires doctors to believe the health of the mother is in danger, and generally does not permit late term abortions. Now, I'd love it if there were no abortions at all, but given the horrendous side effects of that it is perferable to have a nuanced and well regulated system than the all in or all out free-for-all promoted by Roe v Wade.

I have to say there are quiet a few of ammendments in your Bill of Rights that i would love to see here, freedom of opinion resonates quiet loudly! we cant say anything here without threats of defamation suits running rife. ... 

 
 Which part of this Australian law do you find lacking?
 
 " Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers. .... "

 Sure, having them could prevent obvtious tyranny...while producing subtle tyranny.

 Has Australia been having a lot of problems over it's lengthy history that it actually thinks having such NOW is a needed or good thing? Or, can you all just keep on keeping on?
 
 If it ain't broke...don't fix it. And, if it is broke, don't hire a non-certified plumbler at astronomical fees to fix it with duct-tape, spit and chewing gum.

I have to say there are quiet a few of ammendments in your Bill of Rights that i would love to see here, freedom of opinion resonates quiet loudly! we cant say anything here without threats of defamation suits running rife.

The obvious example is abortion, which is by law an absolute right in the US, even though 40%+ of the population consider it to be murder, because the nature of the bill of rights concludes that life must begin at either birth or conception.

For god's sake, a fresh radish is living, and yet you eat it in you salad (along with the living lettuce, celery, tomato and such). political absolutism - the idea that government should have no restraints on its power, is dangerous.
 
 individual rights are the opposite of political absolutism.
 
 You seem to be using the word ambiguously to make the phrase mean the opposite of what it is supposed to.

I'm meaning it in the sense of an idea being taken to be an absolute truth or certainty regardless of circumstance:

We were having a debate in my politics class around the suggestion that Australia should adopt a bill of rights, the main comparison was with America's Bill of Rights. 
 Unfortunately all the class could do was to speculate on the evidence provided through research, i would really love to hear first hand any opinions from those who live in a country with a functioning bill of rights; whats your opinion on it? is it a good thing or a bad thing? would it benefit Australia to adopt one?

 
 
 
 Interesting question... but I suppose the first thing that comes to mind is "right" to do what? If we are to follow the French for example, they're mired in humanistic ideals - well, rights are subjective, and [frankly] they are paying a heavy price price for it because their constitution grants people rights by the state. People are not the inspiration... the immediate need is, that's a problem because what if the immediate need is to extinguish the voice of reason that could bring balance to a crisis situation? People become pawns then... especially when a self indulgent piece of legislation floats across the floors of the French Parliament, what then? If you are to adopt a strategy as one looking at humanity for what it is, precious and worth defending - you want to adopt a plan that benefits man at his core... not as he is living at the moment. 
 
 Thus eliminating subjectivity and finding the core reality that binds a people of all ethnicities, gender and creeds together. Ours was based on our founders faith in a Creator who endowed man with a basic ability to provide, defend and walk this earth without being accosted by ideals or philosophies that say he is anything less that what is plainly evident. To contribute to his/her own well being - to worship as they please without government interference [not the other way around]... and to make a living with using his or hers God given talents, without government interventionism. So the question that goes before Australian people [and I am a huge fan of Prime Minister Howard - BTW] is how to model this bill of rights? After a humanistic model pressing a priority of self gratification over a principled and morally clear model, extolling the virtues self-control, propriety and common sense. That has to be answered first... in all fairness, that is square one. Either principles that have historically empowered and challenged - but [typically] haven't been the most populist or popular by th self indulgent, but have built character, inspired and blessed those who practice them and engage the culture under those principles. Or preferring a system that has been molded [quite conspicuously] out of idealogical expediency - benefiting those living in the now - with no thought toward a tomorrow or the consequences of living in such a manner. Those are the questions for your people to weigh and consider first I would suppose.
 
 Like I said... interesting thoughts and question Holly, you and I don't agree on much - but we don't disagree on much either.
 
 
 -That Darn Republican
Do you mean "ex-Prime Minister Howard"? The racist warmongering follower of Bush? Why am I not surprised?

I think the inclusion of a bill of rights in our constitution was the single biggest mistake our nation ever made. 
 
 It was argued by many at the time that such an inclusion would focus attention only on the rights enumerated and since you could not possibly enumerate all the rights that people SHOULD have, the creation of a bill of rights that recognize some rights and ignore others would essentially end up limiting our rights to only those listed. They argues that without a bill of rights the attention of the public would be put where it belongs...on limiting government to the relatively few powers granted in the constitution and that if the government was kept within those confines, it would be virtually impossible for them to infringe on your rights.
 
 It turned out that they were 100% correct. Our government has grown completely out of control...WAY outside of its constitutional mandate...and people have basically allowed/ignored it as long as they do not infringe on the few rights listed in the bill of rights. 
 
 When they were done expanding and snatching up every right that was typically considered the right of free man that was NOT listed in the bill of rights, they started sniping at listed rights, but by now the government has grown so massive and stolen so much power that there is little that anybody can do about it.

"The EU doesn't only exist for the purposes of the single currency, that's a relatively recent development and not all EU members use it." 
 
 
 No, you are flatly incorrect... the European community has been trying to devise a way to leverage their collective buying power against the dollar since WWII, this was a slow rolling very carefully planned out amalgamantion of markets to prop up the Euro - now, what can be said is that there are many nations that didn't want to participate. But the EU is a play at Leauge of Nations... currency first, then defense. The EU has a defense force... a constitution based on humanism [big surprise there]... shall I keep going?
 
 
 
 
 "The main purpose of the EU is to undermine the protections that workers in EU countries enjoy, privatise public utilities and open them to private profit. The EU is an engine of free market capitalism."
 
 
 Well, simply put... that is what they tell people, it's what smart folks call hedging their bets. But make no mistake the purpose of the EU is to go toe-to-toe with the US economy to ease economic trade deficits and currency imbalances and the uisher in a big chunk of the globe in one world government. That's what they won't tell you that is plain to the eye... who are they fooling?

Here money is like liberal social values... what they say it is. When in reality it's a dime short of nickle. We got a lot of work to do here... a lot.

Nonsense. Speech, religion, freedom of the press and expression are all just choices they are not inborn qualities.

 You obviously do not work in industry, or you would know that if you want top quality, advanced industrial equipment Germany is your first stop, possibly followed by Taiwan if you cant take the sticker shock on the german stuff.
 
 
Yeah, well when your currency is the highest rated - backed by gold, why should you budge? they Brits were smart, they like their money the old fashioned way - valuable!  We will add economics to history on the list of things you feel passionately about, but apparently know nothing at all about.

 That isn't true - it is not a debt suspense note like the US dollar. It is back predominately by precious metals and hasn't moved from that. 
 
 
 "Given that I live in the EU and have rather greater knowledge of it than you do, perhaps you might like to reconsider telling me based on a view from 3000 miles away how the place is run."

The British pound sterling measurement was subsequently adopted, the US, then abandoned in 1967 by Marxist influenced "One Worlders" in the Johnson cabinet... and his "Great Society" bullcrap... it was all rhetotic and no reality, fully knowning that you can only float debt so long before chips get called in.

That is what is going on over here... unchecked spending - the goverment overreaching into everyones life... if people don't spend when times are tight, why is the government?  You are one piece of work. In your first sentence you bring up personal choice, that I agree with. It is my personal choice to be who I am, to choose who I love, have sex with, who I marry, and who and what structure my family takes.
 
 In the next sentence you say we must submit to instruction as if we have no choice.
 
 Which is it?

That isn't true - it is not a debt suspense note like the US dollar. It is back predominately by precious metals and hasn't moved from that. 

 
 No it isnt. You have no idea what you are talking about.
 
 From the Bank of Englands web page:
 
 Bank of England|Banknotes|More About Banknotes|Banknote FAQs
 
 
The words "I promise to pay the bearer on demand the sum of five [ten/twenty/fifty] pounds" date from long ago when our notes represented deposits of gold. At that time, a member of the public could exchange one of our banknotes for gold to the same value. For example, a £5 note could be exchanged for five gold coins, called sovereigns. But the value of the pound has not been linked to gold for many years, so the meaning of the promise to pay has changed. Exchange into gold is no longer possible and Bank of England notes can only be exchanged for other Bank of England notes of the same face value. Public trust in the pound is now maintained by the operation of monetary policy, the objective of which is price stability. 

 
 The pound has no been backed by anything since the Breton woods agreement, when it was backed by US dollars and, by proxy, gold. It was, in fact, the british trying to actually redeem their dollars for gold that forced the US to abandon Bretton Woods because it turned out that we had overprinted by a WIDE margin and did not have nearly enough gold for such a redemption.

"You are one piece of work."
 
 
 No, my friend... you are.
 
 
 
 "In your first sentence you bring up personal choice, that I agree with."
 
 Of course you do.. on face value, until things get uncomfortable... in the choices we make, or the conviction that tells us that maybe we made a bad one... then you have problems. never bearing in mind what the purpose of law is for, to show where you fall short... in other words to sheppard choices by indicating which choices are lawful and which ones aren't - it's that simple. It varies form nation and culture, here you were born into a society that values principles over preference. I understand you value to exact opposite... 
 
 
 "It is my personal choice to be who I am, to choose who I love, have sex with,"
 
 
 This is true insomuch as it is within the framework of the limits of the law... no one would argue that. Homosexuals in this country have been survived by the grace of those who live and let live - other cultures are less tolerant, but more liberal voices among your set want to take things a step further by asking people to ignore their convictions and morally equivocate a historically reviled behavior with that which actually a benefit to society, the people have resoundingly rejected any other notion.
 
 
 "who I marry, and who and what structure my family takes."
 
 Most homosexuals are far more intellectually honest about this "marriage" issue than you... they are about fresh meat, and that's it. This is about lust... and catering to it. Marriage is antithetical to that... so both cannot be true Mathew, lastly - your behavior does not have the right to coexist with the same respect a universally respected institution such as marriage between heterosexual couples has.
 
 
 "In the next sentence you say we must submit to instruction as if we have no choice. Which is it?"
 
 You just verified the whole reason why we have trouble in law... politics and education today with the left. You are so busy trying to parse what you can handle... you reject what was presented to come to an understanding of it. Read what I said... submission is a choice, you either submit to what is being instructed or rebel and ignore it. Both are choices... Learning occurs when your mind can be taught, it cannot be taught when it is guarded for any reason. If you are parsing what is presented - you are saying you are having trouble with the reality of what is there... then you summarily reject or refrain from being instructed. Knowledge comes from understanding... understanding comes from being teachable... being teachable comes from submission to instruction, and that comes from a heart that wants to be instructed, but that is a personal choice. That is what life is... a series of acceptances and rejections all based on preference or principle... Thus us the reason we poor and rich... dumb and smart, etc. choices. Here, we don;t penalize other people those the choices of others.
 
 
 
 -That Darn Republican
